dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPENING CREDITS and MUSIC play as dawn breaks over the city by the bay. Sounds of intense SEXUAL EXERTION FADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what is more workout than lovemaking, NELSON MOSS (36) thrusts vigorously into ANGELICA (32), lying spread- eagled on her back. An ALARM goes off, and on cue, Nelson climaxes. OPENING CREDITS and MUSIC FADE OUT. Finished, Nelson hops to his feet on his way...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That was good... Ambivalent, Angelica watches as Nelson enters the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Top dog, big dog, bad dog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson showers.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Who's the best dog? It's my dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towel-wrapped, Nelson keeps talking as he crosses the room.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It's the big, bad dog. Angelica pulls on her underwear as she watches Nelson exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The penthouse is orderly and stark. Entering, Nelson grabs an incoming fax, turns on a coffeemaker and picks up a remote control. Ignoring a stunning view of the city, he closes the blinds and turns ON FIVE TELEVISIONS.  4/5/00 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fax in hand, Nelson speed-dials on a cell phone as he passes Angelica. Entering a walk-in closet, he dresses in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Number one dog, dog at the top --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Slow down. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Vince?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) How about those Vitagirl numbers?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah, looking good. (to Angelica, fake innocent) Talk about what? He sees the look on her face, turns his head, rolls his eyes and mouths "us" as she says:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Us. He mouths "shit," then turns to flash her a reassuring smile, holding up a finger to wait as he finishes his call.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're T-minus 72 hours from fast food fame or oblivion. Ready to sign off on this copy? Nelson makes an apologetic face to Angelica, uses work to avoid dealing with her, hurries into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Almost. Meet you in twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone, and takes a deep breath. He is in a state of extremely jangled nerves. He pours a giant coffee, praying Angelica will stay in the bedroom as he channel-surfs on all five TVs, stopping on a hot dog commercial. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Catching a good one, he switches sets to the same channel. Braces himself as she enters, wearing undies.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Us. Right. Hey -- isn't there some kinda limit on 'us' talks? You know, one okay, two if necessary, three, cruel and unusual. He flashes a smile and bolts, evading her once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson re-enters the closet and finishes dressing, obsessed.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Good dog, great dog...

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: You forgot about my parents, didn't you? He did.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I can't make it. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Nelson, this is their third trip to the city. This is important to me.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: And this account is very important to me. (sees how hurt she is) Come on, it's Doctor Diggety, it's practically an American institution. (stops) Hey -- does that play? American institution --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Stop it -- you know there are actually people who don't work 24 hours a day. They stop. Relax. Have lives. Dressed in chic clothes, Nelson grabs his suitcase. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I'm late for mine. He rushes out, the door slamming shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleepy Madison Avenue types surround Nelson, wide awake as he talks on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: -- Look, I'm not sure I like the tagline anymore, it's working too hard, needs to be deadpan. I wanna play with it for a few hours --

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) Cut it out, man, copy's good. Apply the ‘If it ain't broke' rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator opens onto an advertising agency, abuzz with activity. Nelson is met by VINCE HOLLAND (36). Walking side-by-side, both men continue talking into their phones.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (over phone) That rule applies to mediocrity. We want perfection.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: (over phone) What we want is a check, Nelson. And bonuses. And promotions. You worry too much.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I worry because worrying about losing keeps you winning. Suddenly aware of themselves, they pocket their phones as an OFFICE MANAGER hands Nelson an advertising award.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Congrats, Nelson. You got the Ad Age for the Pelican spot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Unimpressed, Nelson starts to hand the award to his secretary, BEATRICE (23) -- when Vince plucks it away.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You'll hide it like all the others. Whereas I'll take it and put it where it belongs. Over my bed. Nelson picks up a stack of trades as he blows by Beatrice's desk on the way into his office. Vince follows him in.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Moss. Vince. Greeting her, Nelson ignores Beatrice. Vince flirts.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON AND VINCE
dialogues.text: Morning, Beatrice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A temple of California corporate cool, the place looks like a hip playpen for a kid who never grew up. Nelson immediately settles down to work, furiously typing new copy into his computer as Vince nervously peers over his shoulder to observe the changes, wants to distract him, change subject.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Hey, did you hear? Edgar Price is coming out of retirement. Says everybody's ripping him off; might as well get back in the game and rip himself off.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Edgar Price, huh? He's great.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Remember that Mercedes spot he did... a trillion years ago? (folds hands together as if in prayer) Genius.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well maybe a trillion years from now some guy will say the same about you. If you get off your butt and work on this tag. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The door opens and their boss, RAEFORD DUNNE, pokes his head in. He is as anxious as Vince and Nelson about this account.

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: How's my dream team? Got it locked up?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sure, chief. Just finessing some --

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Minor details. Minor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson and Vince are walking into an art department.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Can't wait to show you these boards -- I mean, they came out great, perfect. The best work I've ever done -- of course with your help -- (pauses ) Client's gonna love ‘em. By now they are inside the room and Nelson is quickly surveying a set of storyboards which we don't see. He jabs a finger as he indicates each one, all business.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Make this night.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nelson --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Give me a bonfire.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nelson, stop --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Make this three quarter. (points to another board) Nastier. Give me more cleavage, more dogs --

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nelly -- stop, stop, stop! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Just then, Beatrice enters the room, relieved to find Nelson there.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: There you are. Did you forget your one o'clock at the D.M.V.?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sort of. Reschedule.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: The deadline to renew is today.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: So let it expire.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: It was expired when you got the ticket. That's why you have to go.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Beatrice, I don't have time for this. Wait till the presentation's over...

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: If you don't renew today, they'1l suspend your license, which means the next time you get pulled over, they can throw you in jail. And I bet you don't have time for that, either. A hush falls over the room.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nobody beats the D.M.V., Nels. Not even you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson is in hell. The "appointments" line is endless, and a BABY behind him is SCREAMING. Checking his watch, Nelson is scribbling more copy in a notebook as the BABY'S PITCH climbs HIGHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annoyed beyond belief, Nelson waits as a PROCTOR passes out tests to a room full of random San Franciscans. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: There'll be no talking, eating,or drinking. If your personal hygiene becomes a distraction, you will be asked to leave -- Running late, SARA (25), stumbles into the room. At the same time, the paper bag in her arms ruptures, spilling a motley assortment of groceries. She gets down on her hands and knees starts picking them up, reaches for a salami log under Nelson's chair...

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: If you need to go to the bathroom, raise your hand.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Can you just pass me the Columbo...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: The...?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: The salami... under your chair.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: You cannot take the test in the bathroom. Nelson reaches for the salami, hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: If you do not come back from the bathroom, you cannot pass the test. During this, Sara has taken a seat next to Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: You may begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway through the test, Nelson is beginning to fray.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Falling rock zone... Christ. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nelson's eyes wander over to Sarah's test.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hey. Psst. Sara gives him a "cut it out" look and returns to her test.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Number nine. True or false?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What? You wonder why? What?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Bring your test forward! Nelson hunkers down.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, you.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: But I was just trying to tell him to stop... She's too ethical to rat, too annoyed to let him off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: «+. talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Bring your test forward! Sara reluctantly approaches the Proctor, who takes her test.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: You may retake the test in 30 days.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What?! 30 days! That's a long time -- that's so unfair! I wasn't doing anything -- The immovable Proctor grimly shakes his head, points to door. Steaming, Sara returns to her desk. Gathering her things, she glares balefully at Nelson, who pretends not to notice.  15 4/5/00 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson, talking on his phone, emerges from the DMV.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Nelson Moss for Vince. Did Rubin tweak the music?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, he said it's fine.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Cut him. Get Johnson McDonald, give him the sample, he'll know what I want. Just then he notices Sara sitting on the hood of his bran new Mercedes, she gives him a jaunty wave.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: How'd the test go? Hope you passed. He ignores her for a moment, something has caught his eye -- a beaten-up van with yapping dogs painted on it and the words: "BARKING MAD DOG GROOMERS AND DAY CARE. Sanity in a dog-eat-dog world.’ It is parked next to his Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, Vince, what about this? ‘Barking mad for Doctor Diggety. Sanity in a dog-eat-dog world.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) Now I know you've lost your mind.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Congratulations, you can read. She keeps sitting on his hood, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (to Vince) Call you back. He hangs up. Slowly walks over to her, not thrilled that she's sitting on his car.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Can you help me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah. She keeps staring, says nothing. He feels pinned by her gaze, peers around, then points to her van.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh -- that must be your van.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This must be your car.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: And you can't drive? Right, right. This is how you make -- He reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, right. Well, how much do you make? Doesn't look like much. I'll cover your expenses -- (reaches for money, decides against it, pulls out business card instead) Here, call my secretary, she'll take care of it -- She takes the card, peers quizzically at it.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Is this quest for redemption coming from true remorse, or are you just worried that my sitting on your car will leave a big dent?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: The dent, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. There's a flicker of recognition in her eyes, as if she has confirmed something in her own mind. He gestures to her -- get up. She doesn't budge. Annoyed, he reaches in his wallet and shoves a hundred dollar bill at her.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Buying redemption. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (refuses money) Oh, redemption's not for sale today.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Okay, I guess I'm going to hell. Get off my car. Stunned, she gets off his CAR as he scrambles inside and ROARS out of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson works out at an intense pace on an treadmill as he watches all five TV's. Other than shelves of glass vases and ceramics, the only other decor is a fish tank occupied by a lone fish. The MICROWAVE BEEPS, Nelson jumps off mumbling:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What is it? It's a hot dog. It's a hot dog. It's a... Opening the oven, he grabs a hot dog, nearly burns his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It's a hot dog. (eureka) That's right! It's a hot dog! It's a hot dog! He cuts it and jabs a piece on a fork, just as the INTERC BUZZES. As he speaks he stares at the hot dog on fork.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over intercom) Mr. Moss, this is Manny downstairs, I gotta bit of a situation here. A certain lady, she says... (whispers, embarrassed) Some very strange and personal things about you. Nelson still stares at the hot dog on fork, transfixed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over intercom) Give me that thing.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: (over intercom) Miss, you can't do -- Nelson hears SCUFFLING sounds filter over the INTERCOM. Then Sara's voice wafts up, honeyed and seductive.

dialogues.speaker: SARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, big spender, come down here. I can't stop thinking about you. Nelson's bewildered, and intrigued. Checks his watch, mutters:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ten minutes. (presses "talk") Okay. Be right down. As he walks away, he takes a bite of the hot dog on fork and nearly gags before spitting it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In sweats, Nelson comes out of the elevator. Sara is busy listening to a besotted MANNY tell her his whole life story.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: -- And then my ex-wife, she say you can't fix nothing, Manny, and she leaves me for plumber -- Sara finally notices Nelson approaching, flashes a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Look at that, Manny. My very own Prince Charming. (to Nelson) I don't think I've ever met such a royal asshole in my whole life. Nelson stops in his tracks, staggered. She is off ona toot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Does your mother know you treat women like hookers? Or did she raise you to think being nice means patronizing the whole world?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. I smell a problem. Nelson grabs Sara by the arm, whisks her outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson and Sara face off in the street.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: How did you find me? She holds up the business card he gave her.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm smart. (pauses ) And I need a ride.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: This is a joke, right? (as she shakes her head) You want a ride -- from me?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Yep. Face it, it's your fault I can't drive. The least you can do is schlep me somewhere. It's quick, painless --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I am not a schlepper. Manny knocks on the glass from the inside and holds up a handwritten sign that reads, "You want me call police?" Nelson shakes his head. Turns back to Sara.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Been a ball, but some of us have to work.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Don't make me go too far. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He makes a gesture, cutting her off, heads toward the entrance, Sara stops a clean-cut couple entering the building.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Maybe you can help? This man -- he's your neighbor, right -- has been standing naked in his window flashing his ass at me and I want him to stop --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ignore her, please. As the flustered couple scurries inside, Sara stops a young woman on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hi, how are you? We've got a case of vodka and a bathtub full of fudge upstairs, would you like to join us?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Stop it or I'll call the police.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Great. Go ahead. I love the police.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Do you have any shame at all? (pauses ) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picture of displeasure, Nelson drives. Sara checks out the luxe car, the leather, the lights on dash. Not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: By the way, my name's Sara Deever. (points) Okay, get in the right lane, put your turn signal on --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I know how to drive!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You want to take the 80 to Oakland -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oakland? You said this would be quick.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I said it would be painless, too. Then, she flashes a warm, disarming smile, full of charm -- completely throwing him yet again.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's so nice of you to do this for me, Nelson. Sorry if I went too far, but I really did need the ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the midst of an industrial district, the Mercedes pulls up near a nondescript building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara pulls a flaming red wig out of her bag and puts it on. Nelson is not amused.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ha-ha. What do you plan to do with that?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Commit a heinous crime. You'll wait, won't you? Sara snatches the keys out of the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Of course you will. She climbs out. Nelson bangs his head against the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara approaches the building. She goes in. Moments later, an ALARM BLARES.  23 24 25 26 27 4/5/00 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ALARM CLANGING, Nelson is frozen, completely terrified, realizing this could be far more serious than he imagined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying lumpy sacks, Sara flees the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara jumps in and jams the keys in the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Go! Go! Go! Nelson is so frightened, he obeys her and FIRES UP the CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson's CAR SCREECHES into motion.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Don't you feel like Bonnie and Clyde?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: They got shot. Don't open it -- I don't wanna know! This is coercion -- entrapment!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Will you relax? They're just... To Nelson's amazement, Sara removes two squirming Jack Russell puppies from the bag.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: .+. some fine furry friends. (kisses puppies) Somebody was gonna slice open your little heads and do nasty experiments on your brains, weren't they? She lets them go as the car stops for a light. Nelson lashes out, furious. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Off the leather, off the leather! (trying to compose himself) Let me get this straight. You humiliated me, harassed and exploited me -- just so -- I could help you in some cute save-the- puppy caper? Off the leather!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Not cool enough for you? Better if we whacked a few people while we were at it? (points to traffic light) You can go on green in California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MERCEDES swerves and SCREECHES as Nelson is assaulted by the slobbering pups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The puppies tumble on the ground, Sara crouched on her knees plays with them as Nelson fills his tank with gas. Down the street he sees a police car scanning the block, its searchlight raking the buildings. His eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Get ready to go to jail, Sara Deever.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You're not gonna tell them. The car is coming closer, Nelson nods, excited.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (holds her ground) Oh no, you won't, I have a hunch about you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The car reaches them; as it glides past, Nelson meekly raises his hand to wave, furious that he has capitulated again.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: See? I knew you weren't as hard- ball as you act. Stone-faced, Nelson admits nothing. Keeps pumping gas.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hey, I have an idea. Let's take them back to my place and give them names --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sounds like a million laughs, but I gotta work.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What kind of work?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Advertising.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean you convince people they need something completely inessential and blight the landscape in the process.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Bingo! That's me!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Is it fun? Do you enjoy it?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: People tend to enjoy what they're really good at.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: So the answer is -- yes? You do. But does it make you happy?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Everyone knows happiness is a myth, an extremely powerful myth -- Sara's laugh starts as a snicker, builds to a full-blown howl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: -- Created by advertisers!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: So what else makes you miserable, besides your job? Nelson doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What do you do for fun? He doesn't answer, but she acts as if they are conversing

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I didn't think so. No hobbies, diversions, kinky obsessions? (as he doesn't answer ) I was afraid of that. What about -- Nelson rams the nozzle back into the pump.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Just get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes pulls up to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Would you like to come up for a cup of cocoa?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: As scintillating as the evening's been, I'm afraid not. Sara is undeniably sincere and sexy, and even Nelson can' help but be tempted just a little.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'll make a deal with you. Come up for one cup, and I'll never ask you for another ride for as long as I live. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Okay. See you tomorrow then. Sara starts to get out, but Nelson stops her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa -- hold on.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Is eight o'clock good? You, me, Manny the doorman, that whole thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deliberately chaotic, Sara's loft includes the fire pole from the old station and plants galore. As the puppies carouse in a pen, Sara sets two teacups on the kitchen table, where Nelson is sitting, aware of the fact that she is openly checking him out. He tries to strike a nonchalant pose.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I can help you, Nelson. I have a gift. A special ability to help men with... problems. Thinking this is a seduction tactic, he plays along.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't have problems.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That's usually the first sign. Nelson groans as she sits down across from him, dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Denial. I think you work too much.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Right. What do you know about work? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: freak? 22. 31

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Plenty. You admitted you do nothing else, and it doesn't make you happy. How's that for screwy logic?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I admitted nothing. I was silent.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: No special interests. No pets. You hate dogs --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Busted! Actually, I do have a pet. A fish. Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Cold-blooded doesn't count. You're a walking case study: we've got anger, stress, repression, extreme distraction, egocentricity, and control freakism --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Control freakism is not a word --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Look at you, you're a workaholic in such an advanced stage that all your intimacy skills have withered away to almost nothing. Left untreated, Nelson, you could become emotionally extinct. Nelson rolls his eyes and drinks his cocoa, checking out her messy loft with a wary look, thinking who is this

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Out of sheer, perverse curiosity, how does a lunatic like you help a guy like me?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You live in a box. I could open the lid, let some light in.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Wow that's deep. I feel cured already, just hearing about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sara nods. 23.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (ignores him) If you want my help, it'll require a commitment on your part. You'll have to live here with me for one month, no more, no less, no work allowed.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You don't even know me, and you're inviting me to move in with you?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: How's my girlfriend supposed to feel about that?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You don't have a girlfriend. I mean, you can feel it... there's something intimate a woman leaves on aman. You don't have that.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Her name's Angelica.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Well you know what? I feel sorry for Angelica.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Great, I'll relay that to her when I leave. Which is right about now --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: October's almost over. We can start midnight on the first of November. If you're brave enough to commit, I will devote myself entirely to you. Nelson gets up.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Brave enough, but not stupid enough. (pause) Now listen up, moonbeam. Here's how it works. No more harassment, no more rides, no more extortion. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next time you come to my building, I really will call the cops. Bye-bye. He leaves. Frowning, Sara reflects on her failed proposal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of a long table, Raeford Dunne sits next to BUDDY LEACH (65). Vince and agency staff fill one side of the table. Leach and the Doctor Diggety brass occupy the other. Leach's face does not betray one emotion as he listens to Nelson's presentation. On the wall, white sheets of paper cover boards underneat Nelson is at the top of his game, a consummate showman. H is so amped up, he's practically throwing off sparks. He holds up a board with an image on it -- a silly looking 50's style hot dog cartoon figure -- Doctor Diggety.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: This is your brand image, Mister Leach -- we polled your primary demographic and you know what eighty-nine percent said: boring. Safe. We need to drop a bomb. (dropping the board) We don't want hot dogs safe. (working up a head of steam) What's in a hot dog? Don't tell me! I don't wanna know... He rips down a white sheet of paper to reveal an image of a hot dog engulfed in flames: the hot dog from hell.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: They're dangerous! (pauses ) What are we selling here? We're selling temptation -- desire -- animal instincts -- gluttony -- sin. We want to show man as he really is... a savage... he needs fire, he needs food. He hunts and gathers, what does he get? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rips down another sheet of what looks like a cave man cooking hot dogs on a grill, his family of savages huddled behind him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: He gets a hot dog! (pauses ) We're pagans, we love our rituals -- our team hits the ball out of the park, we're screaming, we're insane. What do we want? Rips down another sheet of a crowd at baseball game pitch forward screaming like monsters, all holding hot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: We want a hot dog! (pauses ) Let's go straight to your pre-teen demographic. Kids. The little angels. They're not angels. They're monsters. You give them a tuna sandwich. They don't want a tuna sandwich... (cips down another sheet) They want a hot dog! Board showing a little boy glumly holding up a tuna sandwich and an apple, lusting after the hot dog in the hands of a cute girl next to him. Nelson rushes over to another sheet.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: We need women. We've got the mothers, we need their daughters. Let's answer that age old question -- what does a woman really want? You know. I know -- (vips sheet exposing another board) She wants a hot dog! He is like some rabid animal, all fired up.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: We're hot blooded -- we need sex. We need a sinful, dangerous food. What is it? (rips another sheet) It's a hot dog! It's a hot dog! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He goes to the last sheet and rips it down. A picture of a total babe in devil costume, all bright reds and cleavage, holding a pitchfork, a hot dog impaled on the prong. The gates of hell sizzling overhead. The words: “DOCTOR DIGGETY. IT'S A HOT DOG" at bottom. Nelson pauses for dramatic effect.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Doctor Diggety. It's a hot dog. There is a long pause as Nelson catches his breath and everyone in the room turns to Leach to hear his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEACH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (taken aback) No. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEACH
dialogues.text: It's not for us. You don't understand our company.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't understand? What did you ask for? Edge. (points) This is edge. Not even willing to deal with Nelson, Leach turns to Raeford Dunne, as he prepares to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEACH
dialogues.text: We'll be going with Baker, Bohanen. He gestures to his team, they rise, start to leave. Nelson starts to snap.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I think you're making a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: Nelson -- Nelson grabs a sales chart, holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I've seen your sales. You're in trouble. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEACH
dialogues.text: (proudly) No. We are America's favorite hot dog, son. He keeps moving toward the door, and Nelson finally snaps

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Were. You're a dinosaur. You're flatlining. You're dead meat.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEACH
dialogues.text: (spins around, furious) You just went too far, you little punk. I'm gonna tell you what I really think of your campaign. It's cheap, tasteless crap.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Well that's funny, ‘cause so is your product.

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: Nelson, stop it --

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEACH
dialogues.text: I sell a wholesome hot dog, you prick --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It's mystery meat!

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: Nelson, I'm warning you -- As Leach's minions hustle him out of the room, Vince and two other ad guys hold Nelson back. He shouts to Leach's departing figure.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It's toxic waste in a tube! You're killing me! You're killing us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunne storms in, followed quickly by Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: What the hell happened in there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I know -- can you believe that asshole --

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: I've always said you're brilliant, Nelson. A goddamn machine, but one of these days you're gonna snap, and we're all gonna burn.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, burn?

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what was at stake here? How many millions of dollars we just lost? You just ran my agency's name through the gutter --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Gutter? I'm the best thing this agency's got!

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what was at stake here? How many millions of dollars we just lost? You just ran my agency's name through the gutter --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Gutter? I'm the best thing this company's got!

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: Confusing style for substance doesn't make you best. It makes you a wreck. You need a vacation. Now.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Screw vacation! Give me another account!

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: Nelson, did you hear me? Take a vacation -- short or permanent, your choice!-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Are you threatening me? (laughs manically) That's hilarious. I'm two Clios ahead of the game, Ray, you can't afford to lose me --

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: You're fired. There's a dead silence for a few beats.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Say that again, I don't think I heard you.

dialogues.speaker: DUNNE
dialogues.text: I_said you're fired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson hurtles through the lobby. Elevator doors open, Vince charges out. THROUGH plate glass window, sees Nelson outside.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nels! Nelson, wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson tries to unlock his door, his hands are shaking so badly he fumbles with the key, labors to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Nelson enters, instantly deflating. He's very relieved to find Angelica emerging from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: God, am I glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: You are? He notices she is carrying an overnight bag. She musters her strength, mind made up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: No muss, no fuss. Let's try to do this with a little dignity, shall we? She crosses toward the door, past him. He is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: This is not a good time for this, Angelica.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Hard to believe but it's not your call, Nelson. I just finally realized... I can't stay involved with a man who doesn't even know he's not involved. (awkwardly) So I guess this non-relationship is officially a non-relationship. All her efforts to be cool are cracking. She looks away, pushing the corners of her eyes, trying to stop a tear.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: I tried to get close to you. I did.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (panicking) Wait -- please -- whatever I did -- or said, I didn't mean, I'll be better -- She knows he's lying, that's even more humiliating to her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Please -- don't go.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: I'm not staying just because you don't want to be alone. She exits, leaving Nelson alone in the silent penthouse. He approaches his display of glass and ceramics and stares at them blankly. Then, with a sudden, violent swipe, Nelson sends the entire collection crashing. Someone KNOCKS on the door.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Moss? You okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Blood seeps from a cut on Nelson's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You gotta delivery.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Leave it!

dialogues.speaker: MANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm not sure you want me do that, sir. It's from the loco lady? The other night? She said I don't deliver it personal, she gonna -- (voice lowers) I'm too shy to say it, Mister Moss.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I said leave it! Nelson wraps a towel around his hand. Opening the door, he finds a tattered box. Stamped on the lid: NOVEMBER. The box starts to move. Horrified, Nelson lifts the lid!-- a Jack Russell puppy has a ridiculous-looking Halloween hat tied to its head -- dangling from the hat is a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson storms off the elevator carrying the box with the WHINING PUPPY inside.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Manny! Manny! Gone for the night, Manny has left a Polaroid of himself in costume on a sign that reads, "Manny Say Happy Halloweens!" Activated by Nelson's movements, an electric GOBLIN next to the sign CACKLES demonically.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone, Nelson paces as the hyperactive PUPPY races through the apartment -- sees the fish in the tank and starts madly BARKING. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You're a delivery service. You deliver things. (to dog) Stop it! Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not live animals, sir. Too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: So what you're saying is, if I kill the dog, you'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Please don't kill the dog, sir. Nelson slams the phone down and watches in horror as the BARKING PUPPY lifts a leg and pees all over the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding the box, Nelson leans over to talk to a CABBY.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I have an unusual request. But I will pay you two hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: CABBY
dialogues.text: Get lost, you sick son-of-a-bitch. As the CAB SCREECHES away, Nelson becomes unhinged. Starts howling in rage. Inside the box, the PUPPY BARKS in unison. INT. SARA'S LOFT - NIGHT 4l CHURCH BELLS RING at the stroke of midnight as Sara packs a trunk. Seeing beyond the area from night before -- the loft includes an office cluster and a large bed. A key turns in the door. The door swings open. Nelson stands there looking like a disheveled madman. He carries the box over to Sara.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. Stay out of my life. Good-bye. She removes the puppy from the box, kisses it, then flashes one of her winning, adorable smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 42 4/5/00 33. CONTINUED: 4l

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Did you think about my offer?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: The last thing I feel like doing right now is playing the Sara Deever Mad Hatter Game. He puts the box down and moves towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: May I look at it?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why? Ernie has exhausted himself, collapses on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Because I'm a vampire. I know some things about first aid. Nelson warily allows her to examine his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What are you after? What do you want from me? She leads him to the bathroom as he studies her suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara treats Nelson's hand.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: So what'd you do today?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What'd I do today? (pauses ) I got fired. (pauses ) They took the company car. (pauses ) And my girlfriend left me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Define ‘perfect.’

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's November first. Our month to be together.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You're actually serious about this, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You think I'm just gonna drop everything --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Sounds like you already have.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: -- Live here, and let you mess with my head for a whole month?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't put it that way, but yeah, that's what you should do. Sara removes her sweater, revealing a very persuasive undershirt, and then returns to working on his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: So this... whatever you call it --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Help. Sara stands and starts unbuttoning Nelson's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Taking your shirt off.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: So you can clean up.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why? Out in the open now, the sexual tension between them intensifies.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Because you smell like puppy piss. Sara takes the shirt to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirtless, Nelson seems bewildered, can't decide whether to wash up or get out of there -- he catches his reflection in the mirror, studies it for an answer, mutters:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Just for the night. He turns on the water, leans down to wash his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara sprays the shirt with detergent. She crosses the last day of October off a large wall calendar and then tears the month away, revealing November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleaned up, Nelson comes from the bathroom, Sara brings him the shirt. Nelson sniffs it and puts it on. They move closer. They kiss. Channeling his desperation, Nelson lifts her onto the bed, spins her down and pulls at her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Wait, Nelson, stop... stop. Sara pushes him back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Look at me. Gently. Slowly. He starts in just as aggressively, and again she stops him.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Nelson, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What does it look like I'm doing?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Just take it easy. It doesn't have to be like this. We've got all night. He stares at her for a long moment and then pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: To hell with the whole goddamn thing. Nelson yanks on his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring rain. Wearing his suit with no shirt, Nelson storms out the door. Sara follows pulling her sweater on.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Nelson, wait a second! Would you stop for one second? He keeps going. A few pedestrians gawk, but most keep going. Nelson pulls Sara aside.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I have no words to describe how totally whacked you are!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What are you so pissed off about?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: This has been the day from hell, and the absolute last thing I need is you telling me what to do in the sack!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Please come back. I won't tell you what to do. We don't even have to do anything. Just don't go. For a moment, Nelson's guard drops and his face betrays how weary and shattered he is by the events of the day. She slips inside the opening in the crack.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Tell me what you want me to do, Nelson, and I'll do it. Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on the bed, Nelson stares intently at Sara, standing in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Take that off. Sara pulls her sweater over her head, revealing the same persuasive undershirt he saw earlier.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That, too. Sara removes her shirt. Exposed, she waits for Nelson to make the next move. Gently, he kisses her stomach. As he slowly works his way upward, a swooning Sara grows increasingly breathless.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Would you like to be my November, Nelson?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yes. Finally letting go, they meet in a deep, sensuous kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daylight returns to the hectic city.  50 51 52 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/11/00 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in bed, Nelson is sound asleep, jerks bolt upright screaming -- a cross-eyed cat is gnawing at his toes. He grabs the cat by the scruff of neck, ready to hurl it, then guiltily peeks to see if Sara's around, muttering:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Nice cat... nice kitty... Sara's gone. Nelson abruptly drops the cat -- it streaks across the bed and barrels out to the living area where it is attacked by Ernie, the puppy. Sounds of FURRY FIGHTING ensue. Nelson jumps out, throws on his boxers, momentarily puzzled -- where's the rest of his clothes? Grabs his cell phone and heads over to a TV set surrounded by plants and ferns. He tries to turn it on, it doesn't work. Shrugging, Nelson lowers himself to the floor and begins a practiced routine of situps as he punches a number on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince winks at the CUTE CASHIER as he steps up to the front of the line.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Double venti caffe latte and your phone number. Vince's PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE CASHIER
dialogues.text: (ignoring the pass) Double venti caffe latte: 3.85. Wedging the phone between his ear and shoulder, Vince digs cash out of his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Notorious Nelson! Holy Christ man, I been trying to call you. What the hell is going on? INTERCUT BETWEEN Nelson and Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: exercising. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/11/00 39.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Edgar Price.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Edgar Price?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Edgar Price.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Edgar Price? Wha... Wha... Wha...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Can you get us a meeting?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You and me?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You and me. Edgar Price's new company. Game?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I will get us that meeting. Genuis. They stuck with me with that knob, John Headley. I'm dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara enters the loft.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You're a genius, Moss! Anyone ever tell you that?!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Call me. Hanging up, Nelson continues to exercise... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 SWEET NOVEMBER - 5/9/00 39A. CONTINUED: (Al) 54

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Stop what you're doing right now!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why? She reaches him, grabs the cell phone, swats him like a nanny.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Because it's the same boring thing you do every day and you can't do that with me.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Right. (points to TV) What's wrong with your TV? It doesn't work --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Of course it doesn't work, it's a planter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Right. (pauses ) Where are my clothes? Sara walks away, toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I gave them away.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You what --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I got you these -- She throws a pair of jeans and sweatshirt at him. The insane CAT streaks past, SCREECHING. Nelson almost trips on it.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Poor Sasquatch. Catnip overdose.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (holds up clothes) This is not 'helpful,' Sara. Give me my shirt and pants back.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Clothes are clothes. All they do is cover up a body.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it's just that this body likes to be covered in its own clothes. Sara grabs Ernie.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Ernie, you're gonna stay with me for a while until I find you some decent parents. (turns back to Nelson) When do I get to meet your parents? He stalks toward her, eyes burning.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: My parents are dead. Sara sets Ernie on the floor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, I am not amused. I want my clothes back. Now.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I told you, I gave them away. I'll never lie to you. Too defeated to fight, Nelson throws on the jeans and sweatshirt. The jeans are about four inches too short. As he is getting dressed, CHAS (30) shambles through the door, looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I slept three hours last night. Tried valerian root, melatonin... (points to sweatshirt on Nelson) Hey, that looks like my sweatshirt. Chas goes straight to the coffeemaker, pours a cup, kisses Sara.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: You know what finally put me to sleep? Jimmy Cagney. Public Enemy. Violence as a tranquilizer, how twisted is that? Nelson staggers forward, too dazed to speak.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Hello, you must be November.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I must be November.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: His name is Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (extends hand) I'm Chas. Keep the sweatshirt. It looks better on you.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Is this some communal, culty, Squeaky and Charlie type of deal? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 56 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 42.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (laughs) Funny. Much hipper than October. What a wanker. (checks his watch) Gotta go. See you around, Nelson. And just as quickly as he entered, he exits. As the door shuts behind him, Nelson glares at Sara.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I think I'll pull myself out of monthly rotation while I'm ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson exits the loft, and Sara follows.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: -- Nelson, I told you helping men is my gift.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me it was a cottage industry. And who the hell was that, your pimp?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Chas lives upstairs. We look after each other.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem like he needs looking after.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Everyone needs looking after, Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the street, they pass two old-guard bay area hippies in their 60s -- husband and wife AL and OSIRIS. They're unlocking the door to their bookstore, Christopher's Books, with pictures of Ginsberg and Ferlinghetti in the window.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hey, guys, this is Nelson. But Nelson's off, without saying a word to them. Sara barrels after him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 PM 43.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That was so rude! Al and Osiris are great! They were close personal friends of Jack Kerouac !--

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't care. I don't read. Diagonally across the street, a vegetable market. The vendor, a Chinese woman, wags her finger and shouts at pictures of her family propped up on her Buddhist altar. Sara gives her a wave and continues with Nelson a few steps, where they encounter ABNER (10). He wears a red balaclava, practices balancing on one leg. Seeing Sara, Abner stops balancing and avidly follows her as if she were the Pied Piper. Nearby, a HOMELESS MAN rummages through the garbage, incongruously dressed in the chicest gear imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
dialogues.text: Sara, can you spare fifteen bucks?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Okay, now you're just being greedy, Bruce. I already gave you those clothes. Nelson puts a brake on, gasps.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Jesus -- those are my Prada pants!-- my sweater -- Petrified, Bruce takes off running.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Doesn't it feel good to give?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No! Nelson calls after the Homeless Man.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. Give me back my pants.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Are you November?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Where am I? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: attitude.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Nelson, this is a great kid, you've got to meet him. Abner. He wants to set a world record. What's today's project, Abner?

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Standing on one leg. (hands Nelson watch) Would you time me, I have to break the current record of 300 hours.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No. Abner does a head-to-toe on Nelson, doesn't like the

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Nice pants -- expecting a flood?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Nice hat -- planning a bank robbery? Bored with Nelson, Abner peels off in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That's pathetic -- you let a ten-year-old wind you up?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Forget him, what's the deal with you? You sleep with half the city, get the whole neighborhood involved?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Would you prefer I was a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Considering the alternative, yes.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That tender tender male ego is bruised, isn't it? (sweetly, tenderly) I'm yours, Nelson Moss. All yours. That sends alarms ringing in his confirmed bachelor's brain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Look, Sara, you're great. You're a very sexy, smart, interesting, somewhat unusual woman... She just looks at him so guilelessly, he fumbles.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: But we ah... don't know where this is... I always think it's best to clarify issues... the beginning of... I'm not ready for... I can't be your man-man... She starts to laugh so hard tears roll down her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You are the most egotistical lunkhead I've ever met! (settles down) It's one month, Nelson. Get it? Now he's insulted. And amazed. He's never been treated this way before. To save face, he acts tough.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: The truth is, I don't have a month. Time is money...

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Okay. How long can you put your big fat lucrative career on hold to try this thing out? Wait a minute -- you're unemployed --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (stung) You know, the more I think about it, this 'project' of yours feels like an excuse to get laid. That hurts. She flushes, looks away. He feels bad, didn't expect her to react this way.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't think you'd... (gentler) I just don't understand why you're doing this, is all.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I have my reasons. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She starts to walk. He comes abreast of her, chastened.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Still friends? And like a brilliant emotional acrobat, she flips her mood back to lighthearted, done with consummate grace.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Only if you give me what I want.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Time.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: All I can do is a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's Barking Mad Dog Day Care van is parked outside a ritzy building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson stands stiffly behind Sara, who gestures expansively toward a rail-thin Nancy Kissinger-style SOCIETY MATRON.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: -- Nelson's helping me today. He loves dogs. Sitting on the sofa, floor, chairs, posed like perfect little stuffed animals, are Society Lady's six beloved dogs. Immaculately groomed, heads daintily cocked, front paws folded over each other -- they are glaring coldly at Nelson. Sara pats their heads as she clips leashes on them.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: And these are the best behaved doggies in the whole wide world, aren't they? So elegant, so dignified. Just like their mommy.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY LADY, (MATRON)
dialogues.text: (with supreme false modesty) I like to think so.  59 4/5/00 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extremely put out, Nelson walks beside Sara -- each holds three dogs on leashes as they head up a path. The dogs don't pull or tug, prance with military precision.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Always a thrill to explore new career possibilities. How much do you charge for this?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I don't do it for the money. (shouts to dogs) Okay, guys, ready to be bad? All six tails begin to wag in furious unison. Incredulous, Nelson watches Sara unclip all the dogs from leashes and swat them on the rump.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Raise some hell, fellas, and don't tell Mommy! Suddenly, nothing short of pure canine bedlam is unleashed. The six prissy DOGS go insane -- race up the green, YIPPING and HOWLING, fighting with each other, rolling in the dirt, scrambling through mud puddles, BARKING at babies. Overjoyed, Sara runs with the pack, clapping her hands and shouting.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Bad dogs! Bad dogs! I'm so proud of you! Nelson rolls his eyes, checks his watch. Lurches back when a wet, muddy pooch shakes all over him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Get away from me! Another dog barrels up to Nelson. Desperate for a pet, the dog leaps up, licks and slobbers all over Nelson's hand. Disgusted, Nelson yanks his hand away. Sara shouts from f away.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Be nice to Winston -- he's insecure -- needs a lot of affection.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I do not give affection to a hairy, dirty thing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Nelson is screaming. Winston has wrapped himself around Nelson's leg and is feverishly humping away.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Get him off me! I'm going to kill him!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Winston! That's enough! Come here, boy! Winston comes running to her, throws himself on the ground and lets her rub his back. Sara looks up to see Nelson storming off the green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van is parked near a hose. Nelson sits glumly in driver's seat. Outside, Sara hoses off all the filthy dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson checks his watch again. Peers at Sara in the side mirror.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE MIRROR
dialogues.text: She is radiant, clearly gets so much genuine joy from what she's doing, she couldn't look more beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: in van: stares, moved in spite of himself. Feels like a jerk for being so uptight. She comes to the window, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Look at them -- aren't they incredible? The dogs are soaking wet, shivering, waiting patiently for Sara to tell them what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to be a good sport, Nelson awkwardly helps Sara to dry the dogs with hair driers. Winston starts to make a move toward Nelson. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Winston. Stay away. You're not my type. Sara smiles to herself, thrilled to see he's managed to bend, just this little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara is licking an ice cream cone, counting money as she waits for Nelson to make up his mind about his order. Her van is parked nearby.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Thirty bucks, not bad for a few hours work. Nelson's tempted to say something glib, but bites his tongue. However, he can't help but register a look of pity mixed with horror at how pathetic the earnings are.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'll go for the lemon sorbet. She almost chokes -- the look on her face is not unlike the one he just made -- pure pity and horror.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Tell me something. When was the last time you spent the whole day outdoors?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I think... when my parents dragged me to Alcatraz for the day, at the age of nine. He gets his sorbet and they start walking up the street together.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Now you tell me something.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What's so enlightening about what we did today? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as she peers at him, confused) Why is letting some dogs go wild a better way to live than my way? Granted, it was mildly amusing, but I gotta tell you, my third eye didn't open.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: These things take time. You don't have time.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No, seriously, it's a question of values. Why is doing something fundamentally trivial better than living a responsible life, boring as that might seem to you? She is silent, he presses on. His tone is gentle, slightly teasing, but there's real truth to what he says.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: And who made you the expert, the doctor, the guru? Why do you have all the answers? Still, she is silent. He teases her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Come on, show me your resume. Just then, they pass a three-sided bus stop with a big ad for "DIVINE PETS.NET -- America's favorite pet store." Sara points.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I used to own that company, Divine Pets. Nelson cracks up, her timing as usual is brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I did. But after a while it wasn't fun anymore. So I quit.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Was that before or after you toured as a stand-up comedienne?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh, I never did that.  64 4/5/00 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson stands there somewhat bemused as Sara comes forwar with a scarf, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This will be good for you... She starts to blindfold him with the scarf.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: ... Sharpen your instincts. He laughs, oh goody a sex game, tries to grab her.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Not those instincts. Okay, this is the object -- (as he grabs her again) Stop it -- I run around so you lose track of where I am. (as he's pushing the scarf down) Don't do that, leave it on -- count to ten and try to find me. She secures the blindfold and races off. He pauses for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: One two three -- I'm gonna get you! Four five six -- I know where you are! Seven eight nine ten. (pauses ) This is really stupid. He starts to walk, bumps into a chair, takes a few steps more, bumps into a table, a few steps more and he trips over a stool and crashes on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ow, shit! She runs over to him, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh my God, you're really bad, you didn't even get close.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (tries to rip off scarf) This is funny? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She helps him remove the scarf, still laughing. Once again, his flight mechanism kicks in and he wants out. He takes a deep breath, has to say something.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, you're not gonna be upset when I leave tonight...? I told you, one day.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Yep. You told me. And you're a man of your word.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Don't get me wrong, I appreciate what you're trying to do -- crazy as it may seem to me.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That's me. Just... crazy. (sweetly) What are you more afraid of? Spending two consecutive nights with a woman? Or discovering this whole thing might not be as crazy as you think? He is flummoxed for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hard to say. I've definitely never met a woman like you, though.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Good. He covertly checks the time.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: So, maybe I should just hit the road.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Stay for dinner. I have your favorite.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You don't know my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Lean steak, no fat? Her sweetness and sincerity get through, even to him.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Go on, stay for dinner, then you're free to go. No strings attached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson and Sara have dinner on a plant-covered deck, lit by strings of cheap lights. Ernie is begging at Nelson's feet.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Mitch was my October. He was the shyest man I ever met. We focused on confidence building.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Was the patient cured?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: My treatment was a little too effective. We had to terminate the month early.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What about September?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: There was no September. Nelson feigns disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm not a weirdo about it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: August?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Paul was so sad.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Now he's happy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/4/00 54.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Now he's gay.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Happy gay or gay gay?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Gay gay but very happy about it. Nelson has to ask:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: And you and all these guys... Nelson gestures suggestively.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Does it really matter? She flashes the most beguiling smile.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I suppose attraction has nothing to do with it. The smile just becomes more beguiling, meaning: of course.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why a month?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Long enough to be meaningful. Short enough to stay out of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You defy every law of nature I know.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Good. The sound of a MAN LAUGHING drifts over from another porch.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Listen... do you hear that? What a wonderful laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/4/00 55.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She cocks her ear, listening to the MAN LAUGHING. Then they hear a BABY CRYING... a BASKETBALL GAME down the street, a DRUNK WOMAN SINGING like an alley cat. A symphony of SOUNDS: lives being lived around them.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Doesn't life just... take your breath away? Once again, he finds himself so moved by her, he is wordless. There is a long silence between them.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What's your secret dream, Nelson?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'm not much on that kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Come on, everyone's got one. He listens to the SOUNDS, and takes a leap -- lets himself open up for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: My father sold door-to-door. Vacuum cleaners, life insurance, for a while he sold plastic food. We were kind of the joke of the neighborhood. And believe me, the neighborhood was a pretty grim joke itself.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Where did you live?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Daly City, just up the freeway... (pause) Anyway, after dinner every night, my dad would shut himself in the TV room and listen to 45s. Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett. For a year or so, I desperately wanted to be a singer.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You thought it would make him happy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/4/00 55A.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No. I thought those guys were everything he wasn't. Successful, proud, in control... He stops himself -- feels too exposed, shocked that such a sincerely-felt statement actually came from his lips. She feels his discomfort, reaches over and takes his hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'd like to hear you sing sometime.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That will never happen. (wants to go; pulls back chair) Well, time to...

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'd like you to do something else for me, before you leave tonight.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Do the dishes. I hate doing dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson is washing the dishes. Sara sits on the floor, letting Ernie teethe by nipping her hand the way puppies love to do.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: So, what will you do when you go home?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't know, I don't really map out my evenings...

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I know. You'll turn on the TV. Get bored. Turn on your computer. Check out your work. Get bored. Surf the net. Get bored. (softly) And think of me. She stands up and leaves the kitchen. He seems torn, debates with himself as he finishes the dishes. Turns to see Sara removing the last bit of her clothes before slipping into bed.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm making this as difficult as I possibly can. Nelson stares, his determination quickly waning.  67 68 69 4/5/00 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raining. Nelson lies awake, studying Sara as rainy reflections of streetlights roll over her. Rising, he quietly dresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raining. Nelson in his empty, sterile apartment, watch- ing TV. Bored, he flips from channel to channel. Turns it OFF. Goes to his computer, looks at some work in progress on it. Gets bored.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Nelson surfing the net. Bored, he starts to disconnect when he thinks of something. He types in: "DIVINE PET.NET." His face slowly registers shock as the site comes up and he reads.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: Web site: Next to a picture of Sara and a blonde woman, who bears a striking resemblance to her -- the words: “SARA AND CLAIRE DEEVER, CO-FOUNDERS." The company is based out of Indianapolis, Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Nelson is typing something on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: TYPING
dialogues.text: He has already written: "WATCH TV. WORK. SURF THE NET. GET BORED." And now he's typing -- "THINK OF ME."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathed in sunlight, Sara sleeps under a pile of blankets. Nelson tiptoes into the loft, carrying a travel bag. As he approaches the bed, ERNIE GROWLS dementedly, ready to pounce. Nelson points a finger, is amazed when ERNIE STOPS GROWLING, THUMPS HIS TAIL ON FLOOR, awakening Sara. Overjoyed to see Nelson, Sara beckons him. Nelson slides into bed, kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Try to be wrong once in a while. It would be good for my ego.  70 71 4/5/00 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson, wearing floral boxers, examines Sara's bathroom, frowning at the cast-iron tub. She is washing her face.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Don't you have a shower? I hate sitting in dirty water. She lifts her head from the sink, water dripping, and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them are sitting in a steaming tub, she is washing his back.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: See? That's not so bad, is it? (points) Can you grab some more soap? Reaching up to get the soap, he tries a cupboard door, surprised to find it locked.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What do you keep in there? Secret, nasty toys? She raises an eyebrow; mock mysterious face. He finds the soap on a counter, hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I looked up your web site last night. Your sister's pretty, looks a lot like you.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It is not my web site. Not my anything, anymore.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why'd you quit?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It started out small. And it got big.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That's generally considered a good thing in business. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sighs 59. 71

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Everything got big. Desires. Pressures. Lives. Egos. I didn't like the big me. Nota good person. Not happy. And the amazing part is, I got out before it got really big, can you imagine.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No, I can't imagine you with millions and millions of dollars!-- with relief, then beams happily as Chas saunters into the bathroom with his morning cup of coffee. Nelson is water.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Did you switch beans or something? It tastes different.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hazelnut. You don't like it?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Too perfumy. Stick to classics -- so outraged by this intrusion he slaps the

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Privacy? Heard of it?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Hi, Nelson. Nice pecs, you must work out. Me, I don't have time. (pauses ) And you look absolutely adorable. (as she gives hima look, he stops) Don't forget dinner's at eight, on the dressy side. He turns and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Doesn't that guy know how to make his own coffee? (off her stern look) I mean, what if he'd walked in just as I was... (reaches underwater) Doing this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 72 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/8/00 60.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She slaps the water with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Stop it! We have important things to do today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson and Sara stand in a rail car crowded with commuters. As the car jostles and bodies bump up against him, Nelson squirms with discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I still don't see why we couldn't take a cab?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Because I make the rules, Nelson. Rules you must submit to, utterly and completely.
