dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You know, if you want to be a dominatrix that badly, why don't we just go buy you the leather and get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Kinky. Maybe even strangely arousing. But if we took a cab, we'd miss out on all this.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Exactly. Sara studies Nelson, stiff and impenetrable once again.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You know what this train is, Nelson?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You mean besides a buffet of bad breath and body odor?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's 55 lives. All happening at once, in the exact same place, at the exact same time. Imagine how much hope and lust and fear and love are in this car, right now, at this very moment. Look around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/8/00 61.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I try not to.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I dare you. Look at someone, anyone. That woman by the door. A woman in her early 40s stands near one of the doors, her head leaning against the window as she stares out at the passing city with a distant, detached expression.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Female, 32-45, primary household decision maker. Watches 2.5 hours of television a day, spends 27 minutes at the grocery store, values price over brand. Ignoring him, Sara gazes at the woman with empathy and wonder.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I think she's a mother. I think she loves her family so much it hurts. I think she'd throw herself in front of this train for them if she had to. And I think when she gets into bed at night, she makes love to her husband like he was the king of Egypt. As Sara enjoys the fruit of her imagination, Nelson reconsiders the woman, this time seriously.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I think she's got a dead-end job, a husband she can't remember why she married, and a kid who doesn't understand any of it. Nelson's grim assessment rolls over Sara like a cloud, darkening her entire disposition.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe it's worse. Maybe nothing about life even makes sense to her anymore. Maybe some days she wishes she could just quit pretending and end the whole goddamn thing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/8/00 62.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nelson stares, silenced by Sara's sudden bleakness.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You want to go to the dark side, Nelson? I can get there faster than you can. Believe me. Looking away, Sara takes a deep breath and then smiles again, as irrepressible as she was just moments before.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: But what for? We see the world we choose to see. And I think my first choice was a helluva lot more fun, don't you? As the train jostles and jerks, Nelson and Sara search each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurrying down the pier, Sara waves when she spots Abner waiting patiently, holding a paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: There you are! Abner approaches, removing his balaclava. He's a cute kid, just shy and awkward. Nelson wants to make up for yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Abner, you've got a face and it's a good one, too! Abner giggles, as Nelson's PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Cell phones are outlawed in my world.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What can I say? The revolution has begun. She doesn't like this. Nelson answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Call me genius, I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What up, Vince?

dialogues.speaker: AT74
dialogues.text: thru

dialogues.speaker: D74
dialogues.text: 74 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 6/1/00

dialogues.speaker: 73A
dialogues.text: Vince gesticulates as he strides down a crowded sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Friday, November 17. You, me and Edgar Price. (shouts) Pucker your lips, we got the meeting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson steps away, sits on a nearby piling as Sara and Abner head toward the cluster of kids.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You're genius, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: About time you said so... Hey, heard about Angelica. Sorry, man, but truthfully? As much as I loved her, I knew she wasn't for you.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Did you? Funny you tell me now.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you know... discretion, valor... do I smell a new female friend?

dialogues.speaker: AT74
dialogues.text: thru

dialogues.speaker: D74
dialogues.text: 74 Nelson watches the other kids coldly survey Abner, as if he's too soft for this event. The tough kids are showing off their remote-controlled sail boats: Most of them are simple, macho, tough -- they look like Mad Max boats.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When my man skips his usual morning check-in calls, I know there's estrogen in the air. (pauses ) C'mon, c'mon, c'mon. Don't insult me. I have a life. Who is she? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 74A
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 6/1/00 64.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You wouldn't know her.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But would I like her? On a scale of nine to ten, is she --

dialogues.speaker: ABNER WITH KIDS
dialogues.text: pulls his boat out of a bag and the kids start to laugh. Abner's is a hand-made sailboat, full of whimsy and invention, an eccentric work of art.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Oh that's really cool, not.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: What is it? Pokeman's dinghy? The kids have gathered in a circle around Abner, they are intimidating, threatening. Becoming concerned, Sara turns to Nelson, waves him over.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Listen, I gotta run, great news on the Edgar thing --

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Wait, wait -- quick thumbnail -- I need a gossip fix here --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: See you on the 17th.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR LAUNCH AREA 74A
dialogues.text: He hangs up and joins Sara and Abner as one of the BIG BROTHER ORGANIZERS tries to break the circle up.

dialogues.speaker: BIG BROTHER ORGANIZER
dialogues.text: Come on, all boats in the water?

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Except for this kid's. The kids leer contemptuously as Abner nervously steps forward and lowers his sailboat into the water. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 74D
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 6/5/00 65.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: That's not a kid, that's a girl.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: (turns to Nelson) Maybe I'll just forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No, ignore them, Abner.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: (disdainfully) Abner? The kids huddled together, checking Abner out, hiss his name.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Abner. The Organizer comes forward, shaking his head telling the tough kids to stop. As he raises his arm holding a starter pistol, Nelson spots a techie nerd packing up a model submarine on a nearby bench.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hang in there. Just wait a minute. (whispers) Abner is a great name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Organizer raises the pistol to fire, Nelson bolts over to the techie nerd.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Wanna make a hundred bucks?

dialogues.speaker: ON TECHIE NERD 74C
dialogues.text: Covertly slipping his remote-controlled sub into the water.

dialogues.speaker: ON RACE 74D
dialogues.text: The remote-controlled sailboats glide in the water. Suddenly, the lead boat tacks off course. The next lead boat tacks off course and out of position.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Hey! My boat's all screwed up! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 6/5/00 66-66A.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: What the hell -- As the techie nerd snickers, Abner's boat starts sailing in a physically impossible straight line for the finish as the rest of the flotilla has to tack back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abner looks up at Nelson, who winks back. As his boat passes the others, narrowly beating the last two boats to the finish, Abner grins from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: I guess I'm winning.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Hold on -- that little creep is cheating!

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. My boat's just better. Abner's boat nudges the end of the pond; he calmly announces:

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: See? I guess I won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson and Sara stand outside Abner's little house, watching him unlock the door. Before stepping in he waves to them.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Can we do that again? With cars, next time, maybe? Nelson nods, Sara shakes her head. Abner closes the door, smiling. The minute he's gone, Sara turns to Nelson. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Sometimes a good idea is not a good idea, know what I mean? They start to cross the street toward her building.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Those kids were laughing at him. Have you ever been laughed at? (pauses ) Okay, cheating is... bad, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're a father figure now.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Get out of here -- father figure. The kid just met me.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You're a man. When you don't know who your father is, you're not very picky about your role models. She stops, stunned. A Circuit City man is standing outside her building with a big box.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Don't be mad, I got you a little present. A flat screen TV.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That's not a ‘little present' for me, it's a ‘little present’ for you. (sweetly, but firmly, to Circuit City man) Take it back. Better yet, you keep it. I never watch TV. She unlocks the door and leaves Nelson stunned outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying a bottle of wine, Nelson trudges up the steps with Sara, feeling very put out.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Stop pouting, we promised Chas Cherry we'd come. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh we're calling everyone by first and last names now? I don't want to waste my night with Chas Cherry. I want to get naked with Sara Deever.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You have a one-track mind, Nelson Moss. Trust me, you won't be bored. Chas Cherry's a great cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson sitting across from Chas, who has metamorphosed into an extravagantly made-up, gloriously stylish transvestite.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That was Chas. This is Cherry. Chas extends a manicured hand, Nelson is trying his harde to go along with it, forcing himself to be hip, ebullient

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Great, great, this is very -- you know -- Pink Flamingoes -- great outfit, and the makeup, wow. (faltering) Wow. BRANDON (0.S. This wine is so Martha Stewart -- BRANDON enters from the kitchen with the uncorked bottle of wine. Also fully crossed, Brandon's get-up is even more flamboyant than Chas's.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: In other words, perfect.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That was Brandon. This is Brandy.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Brandy and Cherry, great. So. Here we are... surprise! He laughs uncomfortably, working double-time to be cool. Chas and Brandon start to tease him, with a light touch.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Do you think he's uncomfortable? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe he doesn't like... (points to the meal) Lamb stew. (to Nelson) I hope you're not vegetarian, Nelson, I forgot to ask.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Actually, we just presumed you were a meat eater.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Right, right, you presumed right. Lamb stew, great. He is dying, desperate to get out of there.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Could it be the music? Maybe classical Italian opera... just sets you on edge...

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: You don't have anything against Italians, do you?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No, I love Italy! I love Puccini! I love Michelangelo and -- and -- He looks in the other room, sees a TV playing.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I just want to watch a little TV.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Oh, we understand that need, completely. Nelson gets up and leaves the room in a hurry. Sara, Chas and Brandon exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson sitting on sofa, watching a TV ad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: Lycos commercial with man in kilt -- wind raising kilt up dog running to castle -- dropping off a package. Pair of boxer shorts for the man.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I always liked this spot, but I would have remixed it, those two lines at the top get swallowed.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Surprised, Nelson turns around to see Chas standing behind him. Sara is next to him, rubbing her temples.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Who ate them? The dog?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Don't be Cruella, Sara. That's one of Nelson's ads. He won Gold Pencil for it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (surprised) How did you know that? Sara exchanges an embarrassed look with Chas, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I meant to tell you, Cherry, I'm sorry I meant Chas, works in advertising, too.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (smirks, bored) Really? What firm?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Baker, Bohanen... Nelson's smirk disappears.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Chas... Whatley?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Oh look, baby's famous. Nelson's jaw drops, he is horrified. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh my God, you have been that Chas... all this time? (it registers) Wait a minute, you didn't get the Doctor Diggety account did you?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Nelson, does it really matter?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh sure, maybe not to Cherry -- but I bet it matters to Chas. I know it matters to Nelson. Just then, the PHONE RINGS. Sara picks it up. She is still rubbing her temples, as if there's a headache coming on.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hello? Nelson points an accusatory finger at Sara.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: She should have told me. (pauses ) I mean, this is... awkward. If I'd known who you were...

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: You would have been nicer to me? Thanks. They stop talking when they see how upset Sara is as she says to the person on phone:

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I said: he's busy. No I can't talk to you, either. Good-bye. She hangs up. Glares angrily at Chas, really rubbing her temples.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Ten guesses who that was.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Sara, it's not what you -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: How long have you been doing this behind my back? What does she want? She sees how confused Nelson is, tries to make light as she backs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh, it doesn't matter. I'm gonna go downstairs. (to Nelson) I have a headache. You stay. And she hurries to the front door. Nelson looks worried, starts to go after her -- Chas shoots him a look -- let her go.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: She gets migraines.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No, the phone call. Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Her sister, Claire. Long story. (sees Nelson's look) I'm not telling it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly in pain, Sara locks the closet in the bathroom, comes out when she hears the DOOR OPEN. As Nelson enters, she flashes a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry I lost it back there.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That's okay. Gives me a little boost to know you're not perfect. (gently) Feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. All gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 80 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/11/00 73.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Chas told me it was your sister on the phone. Why does that upset you so much? She shrugs and heads over to the bed. Throws on the charm.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Remember the part about getting naked -- we could do that now.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Don't dodge me. (sits down beside her) Talk to me. What happened? She freezes up. Quite simply cannot tell him anything. He is really surprised, and a little hurt.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That's not fair. You expect me to be so honest, so forthcoming...

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: But this is your month, not mine. She sees how mad he's getting, leans in and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Never go to bed angry. Aroused by the kiss, Nelson prolongs it, unzips her dress, slips his hand inside, caresses her back. Is surprised to feel her stiffen under his hands. He backs away, studies her. He sees what she's trying to hide.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You're not feeling well are you? (as she gestures evasively) Maybe we'll get naked tomorrow, tonight we'll wear P.J.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Nelson sound asleep, arms wrapped around each other, both wearing pajamas. Hearing a KNOCK on door, ERNIE starts BARKING insanely. Pissed, Nelson lifts his head, shouting: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/11/00 74.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ernie, shut up. ERNIE keeps BARKING. Then Nelson hears a louder KNOCK. Annoyed, he rolls out of bed and heads for the door. Opening it, Nelson finds Abner with an old trunk beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Wanna buy some junk?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Abner, it's, uhh... a little early.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: I think I can break the record for tallest house of cards, but I gotta buy 75 decks, so I thought maybe I could sell some of my stuff. Awake, Sara listens as Nelson waves Abner in.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... come on in.

dialogues.speaker: ON NELSON AND ABNER
dialogues.text: sitting on the living room floor as Abner pulls one colorful, homemade toy after another out of the trunk. Composed entirely of found parts, the hand puppets, figurines and other toys are wildly original. Believing Sara is still asleep, Nelson and Abner speak softly:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Abner, what is this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: I make my own toys. It's cheaper. Amazed, Nelson chuckles, but Abner takes it the wrong way

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Never mind. Abner starts to put the toys away, but Nelson stops him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/11/00 75.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, wait a second. (beat) Why do you wanna set a world record?

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: I wanna be good at something. As Nelson studies Abner, Sara listens intently from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Do you have any brothers or sisters? Abner shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Neither did I. Abner looks up at Nelson with a new sense of connection.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It's lonely sometimes, but you know what? (pointing to his temple) It makes you use your imagination. It makes you creative. You're already good at something, Abner. This stuff is incredible. Watching now, Sara smiles, as proud as she is touched.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Other kids just buy toys at a store. All that takes is money. This stuff is ten times cooler. Abner, you're an artist. The affirmation sinking in, Abner smiles as he picks up a spider puppet.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: They don't do much though.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Really? Nelson puts his hand into a wild, red-eyed mad man puppet and brings it to life with a silly puppet voice: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/11/00 75A.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I happen to do a lot, young man. Why just last night, I cloned myself and then ate me for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: (smirking) I think I'm a little old for that.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh right... of course you are. Nelson now sees Sara is awake, and they exchange a grin.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: In that case, I'm sure you're also too old for this... raaaaaghhh! Nelson attacks with the mad man puppet and Abner, his kid instincts kicking in, flees.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Aaaahhh! As Nelson and the mad man chase Abner and his spider around the loft, ERNIE BARKS furiously. Cornering Abner, Nelson reaches out with the mad man puppet and taps Abner's spider.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You're it. The chase reverses.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Raaaaaaghhh! Gaining ground on Nelson, Abner rounds a corner and runs smack into Sara.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: No running in this house! (scary alien voice) Unless I get to play! Sara whips Abner's one-eyed alien puppet out from behind her back and chases after its creator.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Ah-hah-hah-hah-hah! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 81 82 83 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/11/00 76.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fleeing, Abner soon finds himself pursued by Sara, Nelson and Ernie all at once.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: as the game evolves, Abner and his spider puppet prowling the loft. Behind Abner, the mad man and the alien silently appear in doorways and above furniture, but when Abner spins around, they're gone. Even Ernie scampers past with Abner's wire dog strapped to his back, but Abner misses it. Finally, Abner outsmarts the grown-ups, backtracks and catches them both in the kitchen, looking the other way.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Ahhh!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Eeewwwwh!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Arrrrrrhhh! Sara and Nelson flee, but someone trips, and as they collapse into a pile, Abner jumps on top, all three laughing hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In very high spirits, the three of them sit at a table outside the coffee shop. Abner and Sara share a banana split. Abner is horrified to see the waitress bring Nelson a fruit salad. Sara whispers to Abner. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I know, don't say anything. A Porsche pulls up to the curb, LEXY, a lingerie model in the passenger seat, checks out the street.

dialogues.speaker: LEXY
dialogues.text: The movie starts in ten minutes. Maybe we should skip it. A MAN jumps out of the car, says:

dialogues.speaker: MAN FROM CAR
dialogues.text: Don't worry, babe, you'll get your cappucino. Seeing Nelson, the Man stops dead in his tracks. It is Vince. He whistles as he takes in the whole scene.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Ooooh. Somebody went domestic. Just then, Abner checks his watch, jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Gotta go. Mom's home for an hour between jobs! He runs off. Vince edges a little closer to Nelson's table, checking Sara out head to toe.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Wow. Well, I guess it all makes sense. ‘Mystery Woman Unveiled’ on... (looks around) What street is this? Where am I? I'm lost!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Um... Sara, Vince, Vince, Sara. Lexy calls out from the car, impatient to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LEXY
dialogues.text: Vince, the movie...

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: (doing a weighing of scales) The movie... the cappuccino... the movie... women. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Just then 78.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: God, that is one of the most astute observations about female behavior I've ever heard. Are you a psychologist?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: (confused, laughs) Funny. She's funny. Right? That's good... (points to his car) Meet the lovely Lexy -- my man Nelson, his woman Sara.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hey, Lexy.

dialogues.speaker: LEXY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: See, they get along. Why don't the four of us go out together sometime, you know, do something depraved? a WAITRESS comes out and Vince stops her.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Quick order. Cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (harassed) Quick answer. No quick orders. And she walks back inside the coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I love this place. I'm gonna come here every day. So I guess the movie wins. (winks to Sara) Keep you women happy, that's our job. (heading back to car) Don't forget, my man. The 20th. You, me, and God. (reaches his door) Sara -- a pleasure, and an honor. He gets in the car, REVS the ENGINE and off they go. Nelson is embarrassed, starts doing a tap dance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: He's actually a good guy. Deep down. Somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: He seemed okay.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I just mean... the glibness... kind of wears you out after a while.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Do you always talk about your friends that way?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No. Fortunately, I don't have any friends besides Vince) (vaises his hands) Okay, I should be ashamed of myself, I'm a lousy human being.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (pauses, doesn't indulge him) So what is it? Some kind of boy's club, work friendship?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I guess so. I don't examine certain details of my life too closely.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Do you trust him? Isn't that what friends are for? Nelson shrugs, then nods, then shakes his head, then nods and shrugs again. She cracks up. He's unaware he's doing it.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Would you trust him to be there for you...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: In a scary situation, let's say. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You may have noticed -- I don't put myself in those situations.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (the sweetest smile) Do you trust me? Aware of what he's doing now, Nelson shrugs, shakes his head, nods. She hits him with a look.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Show me the house where you grew up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A decaying working-class neighborhood; "for sale" signs dot the front yards. Nelson's neglected old house has a “for sale" sign in front. He balks, feigning indifference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the front door, extends her hand to Nelson who's like a spooked horse out on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's just a house, Nelson. He takes a deep breath, still balking, then gives in. Holding Sara's hand, he enters and slowly wanders through the empty living room... memories, images, and sounds washing over him. He is silent for a long time, then:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You remember blue and it turns out to be green. Maybe it turns out we were... happy once in a while. There is a set of double doors half open, leading to a room beyond. Together they open the double doors and step inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humming a Frank Sinatra, she guides him to the center of the room and begins to slow dance with him; after a while, he whispers in her ear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 87 88 89 90 91 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 PM 81.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, I may not know a lot of things... (gently) .-. but I do know how to slow dance. And you are terrible. Now, watch me, I'll teach you. As he teaches her how to slow dance, see the look of pure gratitude on his face -- this is a big moment for him. He is crossing an irreversible line.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: to show the passage of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson lying in the bathtub, shakes his head. Sara is painting his toenails. He doesn't like the color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them buying vegetables; the Chinese woman holds up pictures of her family to Nelson, enjoying his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blindfolded, a naked Nelson gropes his way around the loft, trying to find Sara who is stripping and tossing her clothes at him, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them taking another walk; CAMERA MOVES OFF of Nelson to reveal... he is walking Ernie, the puppy, on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sara cuts her hair with a FLOWBEE, Nelson dresses in business attire. Three weeks of November are crossed off the large wall calendar. It is November 20th. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Every woman I know spends 200 dollars on a haircut. You use a vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Quit trying to change the subject. Visibly upset, Sara shuts OFF the SELF-GROOMING MACHINE.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You made a commitment. Our time isn't over.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It's one meeting.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Why is going to some pow-wow with that slicko Vince such a big deal?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Because it's probably the chance of a lifetime, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Well, if it's a whole lifetime, just postpone it for one more week.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, when Edgar Price says he'll meet you, you don't say, ‘Wait, how about next month?' You say, ‘Thank you. I'll be there.' He's one of the greats. Where's my phone?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I hate it. I threw it out. OFF Nelson's look, Sara produces his cell phone and slams it down on the table in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What if the Great One hires you to start tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I should be so unlucky. My gizmo. Sara digs his memo recorder out of a hiding place. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That would ruin everything -- we haven't finished! You haven't sung for me yet. You promised you would. Nelson pours a huge coffee.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That's a promise I know I didn't make, because that's a promise I'd never keep. Nelson chugs the coffee and sets out to leave, so distracted he forgets to say goodbye to Sara. As Sara watches the door shut behind him, she begins to look frightened.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (to closed door) Nelson, please don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An innocent-looking WAITRESS delivers lunch to Nelson, Vince and EDGAR PRICE (60). Nelson is essentially taking command of the meeting, showing the same cool professionalism he exhibited when he delivered his presentation. As he talks, Edgar Price studies him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: We know a lot of guys who do this for the awards, Mr. Price, but that's not us. Vince thoughtfully nods his head, then flashes a wicked smile.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean we don't get the awards.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: But still... we're not about acclaim, hand-holding, dinners, sending prostitutes to the client...

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Prostitutes? That's new. Sensing that Price is a hound dog, Vince cozies up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/4/00 84.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You've been retired for a long time. We got stories for you. Price's eyes light up, he laughs. Vince seems worried that Nelson is coming off as a stick in the mud.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: We're about the work. If the work is great, it speaks for itself. Vince nervously starts to fill the silence, when Price speaks.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: That's all I need to know. (smiles, they're in) That, and -- married? Any kids?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: We've avoided the family thing for some time. All our lives.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Good. Because if you're worried about ‘quality of life' or paternity leave or any other new age crap, much as I like you, we can stop right now. I need to be your full-time commitment. Nelson debates a moment, not sure he likes the tone, but he plays along, playing politic.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I can do that.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: If only it were so easy with women .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chas and Sara walk toward the Chinese tea shop.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: He'll come back, even if he gets the job. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/3/00 85.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about it. (totally worried) You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: My God, I've never seen you like this.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's just that... we still have ten days to go... and he was doing so well.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: What's ten days when you'll boot him out in the end?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Ten days is a lifetime, Chas. (pauses ) I should have locked him in. I should have tied him to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Wouldn't have stopped him. I know guys like Nelson. When push comes to shove, he's only gonna do what he wants to.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That's one of my favorite things about him. It's also what scares me. It's so amazing, Chas. He was changing, right before my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Happens to the best of us.  4/5/00 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Vince is doing a little song and dance for Price.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Just so you know, I've got a couple clients in my hip pocket, some great leads for new accounts. So we come -- fully loaded.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: You're not selling me a car, Holland, and frankly I'm not overly impressed with you anyway. (to Nelson) But your reputation precedes you, and if I have to take him to get you, I will. This is my offer. It's good as long as we're at this table. Clearing their plates, the Waitress spills a drink. It soaks the napkin Price is writing on and pours into his lap.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: You know... we are what we do in this world, sweetie, and you're a waitress. All that requires is that you bring the food and drink to and from the table without making a mess. That's it. So when you screw up something so incredibly simple as that... well that just doesn't say a whole helluva lot about you, does it? Stunned, the Waitress carries the dishes to a nearby wait-station where she breaks down and cries.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Women like that I give dumb a bad name.

dialogues.speaker: ON NELSON
dialogues.text: as he watches the Waitress cry, then turns to appraise Price, who doesn't skip a beat as he grabs a new napkin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 95 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/4/00 87.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: They should fire her. (pauses ) I always say -- a bad hire strengthens the competition's hand. A good general feeds off his enemy.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Actually, Sun Tzu said the last line, in The Art of War.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Did he? Interesting. Price starts to rewrite the offer. Suddenly he stands as if to leave, he's pulling a tactical maneuver to make the nervous.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: That's right. Smart man, Nelson. Price writes the offer on the napkin. Vince picks it up, reads it, jaw dropping. Price grins -- loves his own sense of drama -- extends his hand to Nelson. But Nelson does nothing. And Vince starts to freak.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nels? Are you there...?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Not interested.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: You don't like my offer?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Mr. Price... my father was a poor man... embarrassed by his own life. I swore I'd never end up like him. I thought money and success would be the difference. But you're rich and successful, and I don't wanna ever end up like you either. It's not the offer I don't like... it's you.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 95
dialogues.text: 96 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/4/00 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince and Nelson face each other, both aware of Price on his cell phone only a few yards away. Vince is very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Act normal, he's watching us. Price returns, casually drops the napkin with the offer o the table. Vince picks it up, reads it, jaw dropping. Price grins -- loves his own sense of drama -- extends hi hand to Nelson. But Nelson does nothing. And Vince starts to freak.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nels? Are you there...?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Not interested.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: You don't like my offer?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Mr. Price... my father was a poor man... embarrassed by his own life. I swore I'd never end up like him. I thought money and success would be the difference. But you're rich and successful, and I don't wanna ever end up like you either. It's not the offer I don't like... it's you.  97 98 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/3/00 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson loosens his tie as he exits. Vince flies out.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Okay, what the hell was that? You just shit in God's face, do you realize that?!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: If that's your God, you're in big trouble. The guy's not for me --

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Not for you? Edgar Price is your goddamned soul daddy!-- you're practically cloned from his

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No. I am nothing like that man. If I am: shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Where's the gun?! Shoot me! This is my career, too, you know! (pauses ) It's that new girl isn't it? She's got your balls in a jar. This is why domestic is dangerous, Nelson, this is why we stay wild -- Nelson waves his arm as a cab passes. The cab stops. He opens the door, feels bad for Vince.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I cost you the job, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: No, no, I don't need pity. Not from the man who dive-bombed his career twice in one month. Nelson gets into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No. I guess you don't. And the cab takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara walks down the street, wraps her scarf tighter, shaking. She rubs her temples, not feeling well. Keeps walking. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/3/00 90.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of an aerides odoratum? She looks over. Nelson is in a taxi, stuffed to the gills with flowers. He holds up an exotic purple orchid.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It reminded me of you. She takes the orchid, walks abreast of the cab as it slowly makes its way down the street.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You got the job, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Best offer anyone ever made me. He hands her a bouquet of roses.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: When do you start?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: We had a hard time agreeing on that. (hands her tulips) He suggested immediately. (hands more flowers) I suggested never. He hands her the biggest bunch of flowers of the batch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 98B
dialogues.text: 99 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 91.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: He was the biggest prick I ever met, Sara. She has reached the front of her building. Howls with delight, drops the flowers in her arms. Nelson leaps out of the cab, they kiss, flowers all around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Nelson are holding each other, asleep in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson is brushing Ernie, who keeps squiggling back to try to bite him. Nelson may tolerate dogs now but he's not St. Francis of Assisi -- he fake threatens to whack Ernie with the brush, growling. Sara is poring over a slew of cookbooks checking out recipes for roast turkey.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: How does vegan turkey sound?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Vile. Come on, let's keep Ernie.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Nope. He got placed, he goes.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: But you love this little monster. He doesn't notice that as she sets a book down, she doubles back, holding her stomach as if nauseated.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: There's another one coming soon, I'll love him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Cold, heartless woman. She smiles thinly, the wave of nausea passes and she resumes perusing the books. Forces herself to sound bright. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/8/00 92.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: How does turkey with Cajun oyster stuffing sound?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ordering sounds better.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You can't order Thanksgiving dinner, this is one time in life when it's good to be trad.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: In that case, are you inviting your family?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: No. Holiday fights are a little too traditional for my taste if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What do you guys fight about?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Money, religion, sex, Sara's decisions, Sara's ‘unconventional lifestyle.' They think I'ma freak.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You are a freak.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Anyway, boring subject. The truth is she feels too shitty to talk, turns her head from him to hide another wave of nausea.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'm sure they miss you.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I know they do. She slams the book shut to indicate: end of conversation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 100 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/8/00 93.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You know, there's a good tradition called making up. Try it.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Some day I'll have to. Someone KNOCKS on the door. Becoming more upset, anxious to be alone, she pleads.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Nelson, will you walk down with him, please?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sure. Come on, boy. As Ernie trots off with him, Nelson opens the door, revealing a BURLY MAN.

dialogues.speaker: BURLY MAN
dialogues.text: The password is ‘Mentos... Fresh and Full of Life.'

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What else? The Man forces a smile and gives the thumbs-up sign. Nelson hands him Ernie's leash and follows them out. The moment the door shuts, Sara rushes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Burly Man exits with Ernie, followed by Nelson. As the Man leads Ernie toward his van, Ernie keeps peering back at Nelson who meekly waves, genuinely sad.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why can't she keep one, for a change? Nelson looks down to find Abner, wearing his balaclava and holding his skateboard.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Guess she helps more this way. The two of them stand there watching the van pull away.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You have? Glad to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: I'm thinking: if you wanna adopt me, you can. Father-Son Day's on Monday. It would be good timing.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't quite know what to say, Abner. Sensing rejection, Abner looks away. Nearby, Al and Osiris are changing the window display in their bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I tell you what. I can't adopt you, but I'll come to Father-Son Day if you want.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Promise. An ecstatic grin spreads across Abner's face.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: Wait till my mom hears! As Abner runs off, Osiris comes out to check the window display, waves to Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: OSIRIS
dialogues.text: Hey, Nelson, like the new display?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Beautiful, Osiris. Always had a soft spot for Che Guevara.

dialogues.speaker: OSIRIS
dialogues.text: How's life? How's Sara?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Both are... (peers up at loft) Great. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 101 102 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev.6/12/00 95.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He slowly takes in all the life on the street -- sees the Chinese fruit vendor sweeping up her sidewalk, she nods to him. In a thrift store nearby, a twelve-year-old girl practices dance moves, peering at herself in a mirror. Nelson absorbs it all, feeling something he's never felt before: part of place. True contentment. Love. His eyes roam up to the billboard which was being replaced a few weeks ago. A new ad is up. It says: LIFE IS CHOICE, MAKE THE RIGHT ONE. There is a moment, a transcendent moment. If ever you could see a person have a revelation, it would be right here, right now. He spins on his heels and runs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's face is wet, and her hands tremble as she forces down pills. In raw frustration, she pounds her fists on the counter. Hearing Nelson's FOOTSTEPS ON the STAIRS, she scrambles to pull herself together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson enters, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I have an announcement to make! He stops in the doorway to the bathroom. Sitting next to the tub, Sara drinks more water.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm fine. Nelson enters the bathroom and gestures toward the locked cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What do you keep in there?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Nothing usually doesn't require a lock. What's wrong? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev.6/12/00 96.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm fine. So, what's the big announcement?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Come on, Sara, talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Am I okay? No, I'm not okay. I have a migraine. And I miss Ernie. Sara returns to the kitchen and busies herself chopping vegetables. Nelson follows.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: So, come on, what's your big announcement?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Marry me.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Technically, shouldn't that be a question?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Are you insane?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yes, I am, and you should be very proud of the work you've done. (kisses her) I stood on the street, Sara, and I realized: This is it. Life will never be better or sweeter than this. I am happy. I'm in love. Everything just clicked for me.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: That's incredibly sweet, but you don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. It all makes sense: I want you, I want this life. Nelson's CELL PHONE RINGS inside one of the kitchen cabinets. Nelson retrieves it and drops it into the water-filled sink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev.6/12/00 97.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Marry me. He pulls off his watch and drops it into the sink as well.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Marry me, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You're forgetting something. Sara moves to the refrigerator to gather more vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: We made a deal, remember? One month. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said? I said I'm in love with you. I've never said that to anyone, ever.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Well then this is a really big breakthrough for you -- you can finally say things that you could never say before.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, I know you're not feeling well, but I gotta say... I was hoping for a different reaction.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: We made an arrangement, Nelson. One month and not a day more. That was our deal.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Screw the deal. I just asked you to spend the rest of your life with me. Doesn't that mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Of course it does. Sara tries to turn away, but Nelson won't let her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev.6/12/00 98.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You said you'd never lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Then look at me and tell me you don't love me. Sara's eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Please don't make me do this right now. She heads for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Do what, tell the truth?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (stopping) This! What you want, what you need... I can't give it to you, Nelson. Any of it. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: ... because of me.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What about you? For God's sake, Sara, please just tell me what's wrong. All I want is the truth.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I can't -- Rushing into the bathroom, Sara slams the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara? As he tries the door, Nelson hears her becoming violently ill inside.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (banging on the door) Sara? Sara! Sara! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 103 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev.6/12/00 99.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Throwing his shoulder into the door, Nelson breaks it open and finds Sara, slumped over by the tub, with vomit covering the floor beside her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delirious and crying, Sara fumbles to cover the vomit with a towel as Nelson bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? He sees the key in the cabinet door, lunges toward it.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: No! You can't do that! Get out! She tries to stand up and stop him from unlocking the cabinet, but she's too weak. Yanking open the cabinet, he gapes speechlessly at over 90 bottles of prescription medicine. Sara weakly pulls herself to her feet. Gathering a last surge, she angrily rips the shelves from the cabinet, sending scores of bottles rolling around the (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 PM 100.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: There. Is that enough truth for you?! Are you happy now? Sara hurls bottle after bottle at Nelson. He stands there dumbly, lets them bounce off him.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You just couldn't leave it alone, could you?! You just had to know! She turns to leave -- her body literally collapses and she starts to crash to the floor. Nelson grabs her, she is limp in his arms. He gently lies her down, panicking as she grows increasingly faint.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, talk to me... (as she doesn't respond) Please... just talk to me, tell me what's wrong, so I can help. She closes her eyes. He is terrified, shakes her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara? Sara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bewildered Nelson sits in a curtained-off area ina busy emergency room, being grilled by a DOCTOR. Sara is conked out on a gurney, attached to an IV drip.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Do you have her medical records?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Who's her doctor, so I can track them down...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't know who her doctor is. The Doctor looks at him, taking stock of this shell- shocked man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 105 106 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 PM 101.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what's wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't know anything. I called a friend of hers, maybe he... He peers around helplessly, sighs with relief when he sees Chas racing into the emergency room looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Nelson stands off by himself, feeling exiled and helpless, Chas confers with a NURSE outside Sara's hospital room. Nelson can see her in a bed, unconscious, hooked up to blinking machines and a web of IV's. Nelson slowly comes over to Chas, taps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I'm sinking. Fast. Chas and the Nurse exchange a look. The Nurse goes in the room to check on Sara's vitals.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you had to find out this way, Nelson. She was diagnosed four years ago. It's a non-Hodgkins lymphoma. Nelson is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Come on, let's get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson and Chas share a booth. Nelson has left his drink untouched, is desperately pumping Chas for information.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Wait a minute -- you said -- she stopped her treatments -- (astonished) A year ago? How could she -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 102.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: -- You're not listening, Nelson. For Christ's sake, bone marrow transplants, chemo, experimental treatments... She stopped because they didn't work. (pauses ) Nothing worked. Nelson finally takes a gulp of his drink to brace himself. Tries to be brave.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Look, I'm no doctor... but one year unchecked... Chas holds a clear honest gaze on Nelson

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: It has spread everywhere. Nelson inhales sharply, like someone kicked him in the stomach. He is struggling not to cry and puts so much energy into the struggle, he deflects the emotion to anger.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: God damn it. Talk about trust -- talk about honesty -- how could she get involved with me and not tell me she was sick? Chas quietly sits there, lets him blow off steam.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I mean, what was she thinking?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: She was thinking you'd be like all the others. Just a month. That stops Nelson. Chas continues, his manner gentle, calm.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: You need to understand something, Nelson. Rules are how she copes. When life's out of control, people go to great lengths to invent the illusion of control. (softly) Believe me, I know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: The rift with her family? That's what it's about, isn't it? Her rules? (as Chas is silent) Oh come on, Chas, I love her too, you're not betraying her. Chas studies Nelson, nods.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Yes. She saw what was coming, but they wouldn't let go, kept trying to run her disease. So she took off.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: And came here?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (nods) She told me since she couldn't live a normal life, she was gonna live an abnormal one, best way she knew how. Nelson hangs his head, trying to collect himself. Suddenly,

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't get it, she loves life more than anyone I know, how could she just... give up?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: She's not giving up. She's making the most of what she's got left.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: But... I'm saying... she should fight it, instead of accepting...

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Fate? Why? What's so bad about acceptance, Nelson? all the emotions pour through the cracks and Nelson just bursts into tears and cries like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson steps into her room. She is awake, but drained. The strain between them is so palpable you can touch it. They're like two people spiritually exposed for the first time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hi. Feeling any...

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: (can read his mind) You want to know why I didn't tell you, don't you? He sits down on the chair by the bed. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This is why. She gestures to the whole set up: the room, her in bed, him standing there looking stricken, afraid to move.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Look at us, look at you. You probably think I'll break if you touch me, I'll crumble if you say one harsh word. You measure every step, every thought... (pauses ) That's not how I want you to be. He leans forward, takes her hand and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Then I will learn to be better.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh God, Nelson. If anyone could, it's you. She runs her fingers through his hair. They are silent a few beats.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Will you help me do something?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Get me out of this hellhole. I don't want to die here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson holding Sara tightly, she walks like a child on eggshells, every step hurts her. They pass a NURSE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 109 110 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 PM 105.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: She just wants to take a stroll down the hall. The Nurse nods and doesn't make a peep. They keep going down the hallway, Sara's knees buckle and he quickly lifts her up, carries her the rest of the way to the elevator. The Nurse sees them get into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Wait! She can't leave the floor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurrying, Nelson helps Sara outside. The lights and noise of oncoming CARS disorients her. He steps toward the street, shouts:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Taxi!! Hang on, baby. We'll get you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chas and Brandon wait. Suddenly, the door swings open, and Nelson enters with Sara in his arms. She is moaning, in pain.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Oh, sweetie, let me take her... Nelson precariously transfers Sara to Brandon's care. Brandon barks an order to Chas.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Get the donnetal and codeine. (to Sara) We've got a nice hot bath for you, baby. Nelson watches helplessly as Brandon leads her into the bathroom, where he and Chas remove her clothes. Nelson is so bereft, all he can do is stand outside the bathroom and literally bang his head against the wall. He moves to the doorway as they are lowering Sara into the tub. He can't help himself, has to say something.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Listen, Sara, I know doctors, I can call... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her eyes meet his, she is deeply humiliated, hisses to Ch

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Shut the door, just shut the door! I don't want him here. Tell him to -- go! Nelson can't move. Chas comes out, gently pushes Nelson out, closes the bathroom door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I can't stand by and do nothing, just watch her... (can hardly say it) Die.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: That's why she wants you to go. Wearing an ill-fitting coat and tie, Abner pushes through the front door. Chas immediately slips back into the bathroom and closes the door so Abner can't see.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Abner. Today's not gonna be a great play day.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: No, it's gonna be Father-Son Day. Did you forget?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh, God. I'm sorry, Ab, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: But you promised. Abner looks shattered as Nelson struggles to remain poised.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teacher oversees a room of FOURTH-GRADERs and their fathers.

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH-GRADER
dialogues.text: My dad takes me fishing, too, and sometimes we go out for pizza and he tells me about girls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The fathers chuckle as the boy sits. Glassy-eyed, Nelson seems only half there, but he focuses when Abner stands.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: This is Nelson. He's not my dad, but he does a lot of dad stuff, like he told me I should be myself, and it was cool to be creative. And we made up a game called Dr. Shrink that was really fun. And he taught me not to cheat. Mostly, he's my friend. As Abner sits back down, Nelson smiles painfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson holds Abner's hand as they walk to Abner's house. Across the street, all the lights are blazing in Sara's loft.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I don't know, Ab. I'm probably not gonna be around here tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I gotta do some thinking, make a tough decision.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: She says you're not respecting her choices or something like that? Nelson looks at him, stunned. How did he know that?

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: I dunno, you always see that on TV, women complaining and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (overwhelming) I think you're the coolest kid I've ever met, Abner.  113 114 115 116 4/5/00 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson slumped in back, in a daze. Outside, tableaux of the city glide past the window: a couple kissing against a car, an ambulance careening down a street, SIRENS BLARING, a blind man gingerly heading up a sidewalk, led by a seeing-eye dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The penthouse is a mess. The door to the deck is open, and the curtains billow in the cold WIND. Fully-clothed, Nelson sleeps on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson sits on a bench overlooking the bay. Unshaven and unkempt, he stares out at the water and the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though not up to full strength, Sara looks much better than the last time we saw her. She's pulling a tray of muffins from the oven. Chas is chopping vegetables; they're making Thanksgiving dinner.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Ouch! Shit! You bastard! 113 114 116 She has burned her hand, drops the tray and muffins splat all over the floor. Chas immediately rushes over, concern

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's nothing, just a teeny tiny little... ouch. Her face is red and mottled from trying not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Really, I'm fine, I'm really fine, we're going to have fun tonight. Fun is a great Thanksgiving... (voice wobbles) Tradition.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Come here... She walks over and Chas enfolds her in a big hug. She is spinning, really distraught, afraid of what she's feeling (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: He asked me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: He's not the first.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's the first time I wanted to say yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: No. I let the whole thing go too far.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: For...

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Both of us. Besides it's a moot point. He's gone. She leans down to pick up the broken muffins strewn all over the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: He'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I don't want him to come back. Look what I did to the muffins. She's becoming unraveled, has to keep the subject changed.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Maybe I can salvage a few of these...

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: You know, it's okay to break your own rules, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Where's the mix? I'll start again --

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: You didn't mean to fall in love, but you did... it's okay to admit you need him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 119 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 110.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stands up and throws some of the muffins into the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Stop it, would you? She spins around to face him, eyes glittering.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: What rule says I should put him through hell? All it will do is hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: He'll hurt no matter what. (pauses ) Maybe you should let him decide.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: My life is not his decision. She turns her back on him, needs to compose herself.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You shouldn't keep Brandon waiting. He nods and starts to head out, stops.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Let yourself have some happiness, honey. You're entitled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is set with a motley collection of mismatched plates and silver, decorated with Abner's puppets. The feast is laid out for Brandon, Chas, Abner, Al and Osiris. Al raises a glass of wine in toast.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Happy we-stole-your-land-and- killed-your-people day. Suddenly, CHRISTMAS MUSIC BLASTS and Sara bolts up as Nelson swings in through the window over the fire escape. He is dressed as Santa Claus, carries a huge pack. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/18/00 111.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Sara!

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You mean, Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Not for you. You shouldn't have to wait. Astonished and moved, all of Sara's friends make a move to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll grab a turkey pot pie at the coffee shop. (pauses ) Nice to see you, Nelson. Nelson nods, watches all of them leave, then turns back to Sara. He regards her with such tenderness, she is struck speechless. He unties his big bag.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: For you, sweet Sara, I bring the twelve gifts of Christmas. As Nelson describes each gift, he removes it from the pack and hands it to Sara, beginning with a big salami.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: One: The famous Columbo log. The salami that started it all. (digs out another gift -- wigs) Two: A kaleidoscope of coiffures for the Barking Mad Pet Crusader. He plops a wig on her head and returns to his bag.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Three: A bullwhip for the dizzy dominatrix. So you can rule your world in style, and whip me into shape. He cracks the whip, and Sara shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Four: '‘Sara,' a custom-made fragrance capturing that special something a woman leaves on a man. He opens the bottle and passes it under her nose. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/18/00 112.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Oh, Nelson. This is...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: .»+. only the beginning. Five: Why Is Harriet So Hairy?, the definitive guide to understanding our transvestite friends. (another gift) Six! Tiny Bubbles -- for those leisurely soaks we love so much. He hands her the bottle of bubble bath, then pulls out a plastic Muni train, shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Seven: A hundred Muni train tokens for the the many, many great rides of your life. He hands her the bus, then pulls out a C.D.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Eight: A collection of music to swoon by. Which fits nicely with gift number nine... He grabs her and spins her around the floor as he hands her some vouchers.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Dance classes at Mildred's Academy of Dance, guaranteed to get you off my toes in a week. He runs to the door. Opens it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ten: For the gentlelady who hates doing the dishes... a dishwasher.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Nelson, please, this is too much... Nelson runs back to the door, reaches for a sack.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It's not enough. Eleven: Live in your loft, back by popular demand, I give you... He shakes open the sack, out tumbles Ernie, the puppy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 120 121 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/18/00 113.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ernie! Completely overwhelmed, Sara wraps her arms around Ernie and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: And if this last gift doesn't prove how much I love you, nothing will. LOUD MUSIC KICKS IN as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On stage, Nelson, wearing a white dinner jacket and black tie, sings "Time After Time." In the audience, Sara watches with glee as Nelson sings directly to her. Meanwhile, the diverse crowd goes wild for the rare, unabashedly heterosexual performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Nelson arrive at Sara's door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 121 122 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 5/8/00 114.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You were brilliant, Nelson, but I'm afraid I'm going to lose you to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Nope. (pauses ) Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara enters and freezes. Novembers torn from innumerable calendars are everywhere. Every reachable inch of wall space and half the furniture are covered with the month. Nelson walks up behind Sara and wraps his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Look around, Sara... every month is November... and I love you every day.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: But, Nelson... it's almost over. Nelson spins her around to face him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Who told me once that we see the world we choose to see? (pauses ) This is our month and it never has to end.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: But you know that I'm -- Nelson kisses her lightly on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I surrender all attempts to control life, yours or mine. I live for one thing: to love you. To make you happy. To live firmly and joyously in the moment. November is all I know and all I ever want to know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Conflicting currents of joy and sadness play across Sara's face. She kisses Nelson and hugs him with all her might.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: By the way, that was three things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara retakes the driving test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara exits waving her license, and Nelson wraps his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Okay, hot shot, now that you have your license, what do you wanna do?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are walking down the street, taking in all the familiar sights of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them licking ice cream cones as they look out the train window, talking and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson and Sara gently make love. As the BELLS of the nearby CHURCH RING TWELVE ominous times, Sara stares at the large wall calendar. Every day of November but the last has been crossed off. Kissing Sara's neck, shoulders and breasts, Nelson doesn't see her anguished face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: over the course of the night: Nelson and Sara sound asleep in each other's arms. Later, they disengage their hold, still asleep. Later, they come back together, embrace, still sleeping. Later, Nelson still asleep, Sara awake, reflecting. Later, Sara studying Nelson's face in repose, she is coming to a decision.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 128
dialogues.text: thru 130

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson wakes up as dawn is breaking, surprised to see Sara's not in bed with him. He peers around, sees her fully-dressed, pulling the Novembers off the wall one- by-one. Most are already piled up in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Removing the last calendar, Sara opens her trunk. Most of the gifts Nelson gave her are inside. She adds the calendars.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I thought I'd keep half. I put the other half in your bag. Sara drapes Nelson's travel bag over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, stop this, please... Sara crosses the last day of November off the large calendar. Then she tears the month off, revealing December.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's time for you to go, Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Our month is over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Haven't we been through this a hundred times before? I'm not going anywhere. She puts on a jacket.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I made you agree to a month for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Because you're sick? I don't care if you're sick. The only thing I care about is you.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Then that's why you should go.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You said you would stop trying to control life, yours and mine. (firmly) Now you have to keep your word. She wraps a scarf around her neck, turns and heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Out. To give you time to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara steps into the dawn, trying to stay calm. Suddenly breaks into a run as if she has to flee everything. Nelson careens out of the building in pursuit, practically dressing as he runs, throwing a jacket on.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara! Stop it! Come on, come back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson chases Sara through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara!  134 SWEET NOVEMBER - Rev. 4/28/00 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The park is deserted. Halfway through, Nelson catches her. They both gasp for air.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sara, stop it. Will you please stop this, I'm not leaving you -- I know you love me.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I do, Nelson. I've never felt anything like it. I never thought I'd have the chance and you gave that to me.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Then why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Because it's starting to happen, Nelson --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: -- It doesn't --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: -- If you leave now, everything we had will stay perfect forever --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: -- Sara --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: -- All we have is how you'll remember me and I need that memory to be strong and alive --

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: -- But I want --

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: -- If I know I'm remembered that way then I can face anything. Can't you see, Nelson, you're my immortality.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I want to take care of you, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'll be alright. I'm going home. They know I'm coming. They're ready. (beat) You said I come first. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You do.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Then try and understand. I need to do this.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: It just doesn't seem...

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Just like I need to know you'll go on and have the beautiful life you deserve. I want you to fall in love again someday, be a husband, have a family.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I only want you.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: You have me forever. Now let me go.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I can't believe you've even got me considering this. (long pause) This is truly what you want.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Yes. It is.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Alright, Sara, alright.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Close your eyes, this time count to twenty. Go ahead. Nelson soaks up as much of her as he can. Then reluctantly, he closes his eyes. Sara blindfolds him with the scarf.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: ... One, two, three, four, five, six -- Sara stands on her tiptoes and whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I love you, Nelson Moss. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I love you, Sara Deever.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Remember me.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: +. Seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven -- As Nelson continues counting, Sara walks to a spot twenty yards behind him and waits at the foot of a statue.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: ... Twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, seventeen, eighteen, nineteen, twenty. Nelson steps forward. Then, turning, he walks straight toward the statue and arrives at the exact spot Sara stood just a moment before. Slowly, he removes the scarf. Sara, of course, is gone. All around Nelson, shades of the park emerge in the dawning light. Looking down at the scarf in his hands, Nelson smiles. At the same time, dawn breaks, piercing the park with glimmering, amber light. Carefully wrapping the scarf twice around his neck, Nelson walks out of the park and into the street, just as a red Muni train slowly makes its way across the awakening city, its empty windows aglow in the dawn. FADE OUT.
